Award.AwardTitle: Micro- to Nanoscale Granular Contact Dynamics and Nonlinear Granular-Elastic Metamaterials

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Granular crystals are close-packed arrays of elastic particles, and are effective at tailoring acoustic wave propagation. However, so far granular crystals are typically constructed at macroscopic length scales and designed to affect sonic frequency acoustic waves. This grant provides funding for the study of the nonlinear contact-based dynamics of micro to nanoscale granular crystals. Extending granular crystals to the microscale and nanoscale has the potential to enable granular-based devices that operate at megahertz and gigahertz frequencies. The size scale is also important, as effects which are negligible at the macroscale, such as adhesion, become significant at microscales. Granular crystal will be manufactured by self-assembly. Photoacoustic techniques will be utilized to study the fundamental contact-based dynamics of micro- and nanoparticles, as well as to study nonlinear wave propagation in more complex microscale granular systems. The experimental findings will be modeled using a combination of techniques drawn from the areas of nonlinear dynamical systems, solid mechanics, and acoustic metamaterials. Nonlinearities in locally-resonant granular-elastic metamaterial configurations will be explored.

This project has the potential for significant societal impact, as micro- to nanoscale granular crystals and locally-resonant granular-elastic metamaterials may have potential future applications to areas such as signal processing, non-destructive evaluation and adhesion characterization, and biomedical ultrasound imaging and therapy. It is also anticipated that this project will establish the fundamental understanding of nonlinear wave propagation in microscale granular media. The research efforts will be combined with a significant educational component, and will provide a diverse student group with a unique interdisciplinary educational opportunity in the classroom and the laboratory. The proposed research will be incorporated into a newly developed course led by the PI, and simplified versions of relevant experiments will be developed to generate increased interest in science and engineering through outreach activities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Materials that can tailor acoustic and elastic wave propagation in new ways have become a research topic of major interest. Finding new ways to tailor and control wave propagation is important because waves are one of the most central ways of transferring energy and information in engineering applications, or are often a potentially harmful disturbance that should be mitigated, as in the case of vibration, noise, or impact.

Granular crystals are close-packed arrays of spheres, and are new type of material that has proven effective at tailoring acoustic and elastic wave propagation. Granular crystals are also of interest, as their nonlinearity stemming from the particle contacts, has been shown to give them new useful capabilities, such as tunability, the ability to self-localize energy, or convert energy between frequencies. However, until this project, granular crystals were constructed at macroscopic length scales (millimeter sized particles) and designed to affect audible frequency acoustic waves. For this project, we studied the contact-based dynamics of micro- to nanoscale granular crystals and locally-resonant granular-elastic metamaterials, with a focus on two-dimensional systems. Extending granular crystals to the micro- and nanoscales, may enable granular-based devices, as they have an overall smaller system size that is compatible with a much wider range of modern applications, and we have shown that they affect megahertz and gigahertz frequency waves. This has particular applications in the area of telecommunication devices, such as surface acoustic wave filters, which operate at such frequencies and involve small components. The reduced size is also important from a fundamental perspective, as effects which are negligible at the macroscale, such as adhesion, become significant at microscales. Until this project, there has also been limited study of the contact-based dynamics of micro- to nanoscale particles.

In this project, we manufactured micro- to nanoscale granular crystals by self-assembly, and used photoacoustic techniques to study their dynamics (in predominantly near-linear regimes). Linear and nonlinear discrete element analytical models and simulations were developed to understand the experimental observations and predict unique dynamical phenomena that may exist in such systems.

The key outcome from this project was that we experimentally demonstrated, for the first time, interparticle-contact-mediated dynamics in two-dimensional microscale granular crystals. These also constituted some of the first studies of contact-based dynamics in ordered microgranular systems without sintering or connective ligands between the particles. As part of this work, we demonstrated ways to tune their response, and developed new analytical models to describe their dynamics. These models were important, as they showed the critical role that shear coupling and particle rotation has in granular systems, and described new wave phenomena that occur as a result of the combined effects of nonlinearity, discreteness induced dispersion, rotation, and coupling to elastic media. Our experimental studies also yielded new insights into micro- to nanoscale particle contact mechanics, including identifying a stiffness upshift from the predictions of existing adhesive contact models, and evidence that plasticity and the self-assembly manufacturing method plays an important role. Finally, we also studied configurations directly applicable to engineering devices, that demonstrated effects such as surface acoustic wave resonant filtering.

In addition, the findings from this project have the potential for broader societal impact. Such micro- to nanoscale granular crystals and locally-resonant granular-elastic metamaterials may have future use in areas such as acoustic signal processing or sensing. Because self-assembly manufacturing has become wide-spread, with applications ranging from optics to electronics, this project is a step towards understanding their mechanics and dynamics. The insights about particle adhesion may also find use in the areas of tribology and friction. Finally, our study may contribute to improved understanding of granular media, which is prevalent in both nature and industry, in forms such as sand or powders.  

This project partially supported the scientific training of two graduate students towards obtaining their doctoral (PhD) degrees at the University of Washington, and seven undergraduate students conducting summer or part-time research.

The results of this project have been broadly disseminated through several channels. This includes multiple articles published in scientific journals, conference presentations and papers, and seminars at universities, workshops, national laboratories, and companies. One of our journal publications was also highlighted in online science and technology blogs and news websites.

As part of this project, we also participated in several education and outreach activities that were thematically integrated with the research. Our laboratory hosted two workshops for high school students from the Gaining Early Awareness and Readiness for Undergraduate Programs (GEAR UP) program. We also hosted hands-on demonstration modules for four consecutive years at the University of Washington Discovery Days event. The PI also participated in panels and gave presentations at multiple activities for students from underrepresented groups in STEM fields. Elements from this research project were also incorporated into a newly developed course taught by the PI, entitled Wave Propagation in Designed Materials.
